quiz.title: Unit 3: Angled Projectile Motion (Quiz 9)
quiz.subtitle: Angled Projectile Motion - Problem Solving (10 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: A ball is kicked from ground level with initial speed $v_0$ at angle $\theta$. Which equation correctly describes its vertical position $y(t)$ (upward positive, $y=0$ at launch)?
Which situation allows you to safely use the range formula $R = \frac{v_0^2 \sin 2\theta}{g}$?
options: Launch from a hilltop, landing in a valley below.
Launch and landing both at ground level (same height).
Launch from ground level, landing on a platform above.
questions.explanation: The range formula is derived assuming launch and landing at the same vertical height.

questions.question: For a projectile launched with speed $v_0$ at angle $\theta$ from ground level, the time to reach maximum height is:
A projectile is launched from ground level and lands back at the same level. Its total flight time is $T$. At what time does it reach maximum height?
questions.explanation: Due to symmetry, time to maximum height is half the total flight time.

questions.question: You are given a projectile's maximum height $H$ and horizontal range $R$ (same launch and landing height). Which pair of relations is most useful to find the launch speed $v_0$ and angle $\theta$?
A projectile is launched at 20° and reaches a certain range. Which other launch angle, with the same initial speed, would result in the same range on level ground?
questions.explanation: Complementary angles ($\theta$ and $90° - \theta$) give the same range. $90° - 20° = 70°$.

questions.question: A ball is launched at 30 m/s at an angle of 30° above the horizontal. What is its initial vertical velocity $v_{iy}$? (Recall $\sin30° = 0.5$)
Two projectiles are launched with the same speed, one at 30° and one at 60°. Which one stays in the air longer?
options: They stay in the air for the same amount of time.

questions.question: What is the total velocity of a projectile at its maximum height if its initial components were $v_{ix} = 12$ m/s and $v_{iy} = 9$ m/s?
questions.explanation: At maximum height, vertical velocity is zero, so total velocity equals horizontal velocity: 12 m/s.

questions.question: If you double the initial speed of a projectile while keeping the angle the same, what happens to the maximum height?
questions.explanation: $H \propto v_0^2$, so doubling speed quadruples height.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered angled projectile motion problem-solving.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! Review the relationships between range, height, and time of flight.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on the symmetry and complementary angle concepts.
